text: An old, wooden sign in front of an equally old but sturdy salt of the earth church with a towering steeple. This is GRACE BAPTIST CHURCH of Gatlin, Nebraska and the sign proclaims the topic of today's sermon: CORN DROUGHT AND T
As the choir music continues, picking up the DOORS TO THE CHURCH as they open to allow the CONGREGATION to exit.
We see only the legs of pants and hems of dresses from th little person's perspective. The parishioners are in thei "Sunday" clothes. We don't see the upper bodies or faces. OVER THIS SHOT we hear:
I don't remember everything that happened cuz I was only five then and now I'm eight.

An adorable little boy of about five, his hand firmly in grasp of an adult's hand, is led out of the church. This JOB, and he is dressed appropriately for worship. He come to his father's waist, and this is all we see of the fath and the MINISTER in front of whom the father stops for a BEAT. Job stands there looking around while his father apparently talks with the minister. Legs continue to file past them.
I was about the only kid in church that day, on account of all the other kids had been excused to go listen to Isaac, who was this boy preacher who'd come to Gatlin a few days before.

AN ADULT, also whom we only see from the WAIST DOWN, bang into Job, who goes flying but doesn't fall because the strong hand of his father hangs on to him and lifts him i the air, setting him back down in place again. THE HAND of THE MAN WHO BUMPED HIM gives Job a vigorous apologetic rub across the hair.
Sarah was home sick with mom. Dad decided to take me so he could talk about the drought with some of the other men. That's all everybody was talking about then, the drought.

Father finishes his brief conversation with the minister starts down the steps with Job. It's hard for little Job keep up with his dad and he's constantly whisked off his whenever he lags too far behind.

The door is pushed open by the unseen hand of his father Job is led into the coffee shop. Hansen's is a small, comfortable, homey place that caters strictly to the loca The furnishings are modest but everything is clean and ne Booths with red vinyl cushioning line the walls and the f holds eight or ten tables. There are also stools at the Formica counter, behind which MR. and MRS. HANSEN work busily.
The coffee shop is crowded, mostly with ADULTS but also w A HALF DOZEN BOYS between the ages of 15 and 18. The two waitresses, SALLY and MARIE HANSEN, are about 17. They ar being kept quite busy.
Four of the boys are crowded around a video MACHINE. They keeping very much to themselves.
Job's father lifts him onto a stool at the counter and wa towards the PAY PHONE.
Dad was worried about Sarah, so he went over to the phone as soon as we got in.

CAMERA FOLLOWS JOB'S FATHER as he walks across the room t the pay phone. We never see him fully, only the fact that is very average and non-descript. As he passes the four boys at the machine, one of them lo up and follows him with his eyes. This is WILLIAM RENFREW
There were some other kids there. I thought they were all in the corn with Isaac. Billy Renfrew looked at my dad, then smiled at me kinda funny.
After studying Job's father for a beat, he turns his gaze Job and smiles in a malignant, leering way.
He averts his eyes quickly and spins on the stool so he w have to return the older boy's look.
Dad sure was taking a long time.
A STRAWBERRY SHAKE is set down with a loud bang by kindly Hansen, who smiles at how startled Job is by the noise. J glances up at him fearfully.
A concerned look on his face, he continues on the phone.
SARAH, an angelic blonde haired girl of four years, is tossing and turning in bed. Her face is feverish and flus

HER MOTHER is visible in another room on the phone, talki with her husband, Job and Sarah's father. Semi-conscious her fever, Sarah spills a box of CRAYONS and clutches a B one. Without looking, she begins scrawling on a piece of MANILA PAPER.
What she's drawing is not yet discernible, just a patch o black in the middle of the page.
Job is sucking with all his might on a straw protruding f the strawberry shake. He glances towards his father. Something catches his eyes and causes him to FREEZE.

Thru the window, beyond his father, beyond the boys by th Pac Man machine, stands ISAAC. A gaunt boy of 12, he has face right out of the Old Testament and eyes that burn li coal. He is dressed in black robes and a wide-brimmed hat is staring into - through -the coffee shop.

The straw slips out of Job's mouth. He is frightened to d of the vision before him but he can't take his eyes off o Isaac. Few, if any, of the adults in the room take notice but the boys by the Pac Man do.
They turn and scan the room full of adults.
Look at the boys conspiratorially.
Has four cups of coffee on a tray. She slips a white powd into them from a packet in her hand.
Step out of the kitchen. They have "farm instruments" wit them — HAY HOOKS and SICKLES.
Looks at the boys, confused by their presence.
Is now terrified, trembling as he continues to stare at Isaac.

All of whom have been drinking coffee, begin to gag and choke. They lurch forward out of their seats, gasping for breath as they fall. THE FOUR Boys All whip out hooks, knives, scythes and other deadly WEAP They block the door.
looks at the boys in complete bewilderment. For a moment forgets about the phone.
She is scribbling like mad, seemingly unaware of what she doing or drawing.
It is beginning to take shape. A PERSON, a childish stick figure, but unmistakable nonetheless, pointing....
Mr. Hansen raises his hands in a futile gesture to ward o sickle that is arching through the air towards him. The point of it buries in his chest and a splatter of blood h Job.
tries to pull A BOY off an ELDERLY WOMAN. He grabs the yo from behind but barely gets his hands on him when A HAND HOLDING A SCREWDRIVER plummets INTO FRAME and into his ba
screams but nothing comes out. It is a scream from the deepest part of his being, and it is silent. Mr. Hansen' blood is still sprayed across his face.

The interior of the coffee shop has turned into a scene o complete carnage, with all of the adults who are still al being either cut down or finished off by the Children Of Corn. Chairs and tables are over-turned, dishes and glass broken all over the floor, and blood everywhere.

Isaac, standing fixed in place, is gradually encircled by devoted followers. CHILDREN, from four to 19, gather arou him, instruments of death in their hands all dripping wit fresh blood. Like him, they face the coffee shop and wait
That's how Isaac came and taught us about He Who Walks Behind The Rows.
The largest, most muscular, and most murderous of the boy inside the coffee shop emerges, his BUTCHER KNIFE drippin with blood. This is MALACHAI. He remains there, looking d at Isaac.
Isaac and Malachai.
Sarah is still in bed but is resting quietly now. CAMERA ZOOMS IN SLOWLY to the PICTURE she has completed.

It shows stick figure representations of Isaac, surrounde the other children, facing Malachai. Behind Malachai is a large splotch of bright red where the coffee shop would b Although the drawing is obviously the work of a child, th is an eerie, primitive quality to it.
That's when Sarah started drawing these pictures.
All done by Sarah in the same crayon style as the one we just seen, they reveal part of the story of Gatlin, Nebra Some are captioned.
Shows a cornfield wilted and dry. A MINISTER with gray ha is holding a REVIVAL MEETING in a clearing.
Shows the same Minister from the previous picture being pushed aside and supplanted by the now familiar figure of ISAAC. The caption underneath reads: AND A CHILD SHALL LE
Shows everyone at the meeting kneeling in prayer to Isaac who holds his hands aloft triumphantly. The corn all arou is large and green and glowing.

The Grace Baptist Church. Hanging from its steeple is the gray haired Minister from the first picture. His eyes bul horribly, almost comically, and his tongue is sticking ou caption at the bottom: THOU SHALL WORSHIP NO FALSE IDOLS
A FAMILY, with the parents lying bloodied and dead next t happy, smiling children.
That of a HOTEL, a simplistic version in red brick with b windows, and a BLUE THUNDERBIRD prominently parked next t
ESTABLISHING SHOT. It is red brick, two levels; a real li version of the hotel in Sarah's picture.
A BLUE THUNDERBIRD sits quietly in the parking lot

Morning light filters through the curtains of the room, w is a standard DOUBLE OCCUPANCY. There are a couple of suitcases lying around, some clothes scattered about, and STEVEN KING PAPERBACK on the night table. BURT STANTON, a attractive young man of 28, is lying in bed fast asleep.

Someone is sneaking through the room towards Burt. We do see who it is, but there is a sense of danger counter poi by the peacefulness of the sleeping figure. CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY, STEADILY, TOWARDS BURT.
As the figure sneaking up on him reaches bedside and stan over him for a beat, then leans down closer and closer an with more danger and...FWWWWTTT!!!

Burt jumps up with a start. His girlfriend VICKY BAXTER i foot away from him shouting and blowing a party-blower in face. The feathered end of it unfurls and tickles his fac Vicky is about Burt's age, wearing a sexy, flimsy nightgo and a party hat. She throws her arms around her frightene lover.

Happy birthday, darling! She's giggling mischievously over the fright her little surprise has caused him, and assuages any damage done wit seductive kiss. Burt's heart rate begins a slow descent towards normal as Vicky hands him a SHEET OF PAPER, rolle into a scroll and wrapped in tissue with a ribbon around
Present number one. Burt laughs self-consciously and takes the paper. He unwr and unrolls it and looks at what it is.
It is a TUITION BILL from NORTHWESTERN MEDICAL SCHOOL. It stamped PAID in big, red letters.
Ta da!
Burt is as pleased as he is surprised, and he's very surprised.
But honey, how...I thought your last paycheck....
It did. But I had a little nest egg I was saving just for this.... She pulls out another wrapped gift, this one a long, rectangular box.
And this.... Burt can't believe the windfall. He opens the box with ev more self-conscious delight. He holds up a beautiful WATC His jaw drops. Vicky is equally delighted and excited by reaction.
Look on the back. Burt turns the watch over and looks closely.
FOR BURT STANTON M.D. - My Darling - LOVE VICKY
Burt pulls her close and kisses her tenderly.

Oh Vick.... After the kiss she reaches for a small CASSETTE PLAYER an punches the button. The mischievous smile returns to her face as she straightens up and prepares to serenade him. BARRY WHITE, singing LOVE DOCTOR, begins to play. Vicky silently mouths the words in a wonderfully ridiculous caricature. Burt starts laughing and Vicky can't keep a straight face. Burt hits her with a pillow affectionately  10. A KNOCK AT THE DOOR INTERRUPTS THEM.
Vicky makes no move to answer the door. In fact, she look as if it's completely unexpected. Burt, still in his unde shorts, walks over.
Yes?
Room service. Burt opens the door a crack and looks.
An exceptionally attractive YOUNG WOMAN is standing outsi the door holding a plate with a bran muffin on it. A SING CANDLE, lighted, sticks out of the muffin.
Forgetting he's wearing only his under shorts, Burt opens door and faces the bell girl. She makes no move to enter instead starts singing HAPPY BIRTHDAY.
Is obviously attracted to her, almost to the exclusion of Vicky, who arranged the whole thing. He stares at the you woman, waiting for her to finish.

When the bell girl does finish, Burt is beside himself looking for a couple of dollars to give her as a tip. Vic watches, as he fumbles through his pants pockets, the bel girl not completely oblivious to his attentions.
Watches quietly as he hands the woman the tip. There isa hurt, knowing expression on her (Vicky's) face.

Burt and Vicky are on the road in the blue T-bird. The ba seat is filled with CLOTHES, SPORTING EQUIPMENT, A COOLER PAPER BAGS, etc., and empty FAST FOOD CONTAINERS AND WRAP are threatening to overflow from a garbage bag and the ashtray.
(Contrite) C'mon, honey. You're making something out of nothing.
To me it’s something. To you it is nothing.
How would you like to be standing around in your underwear while some cute guy sang you happy birthday?

(Relenting) I wouldn't mind if it was you. As a matter of fact, it sounds kinda kinky. She gives him a slightly grin, which he smiles at. The tension evaporates. Burt reaches across the seat and hugs to him, driving with one hand.

I know what you're thinking. You put me through med school, I'm on my way out to a good internship position in California, and now maybe I don't need Vicky so much anymore. Right? Her silence answers affirmative.
Wrong. I still need Vicky as much as I always have, and I love her very much. Maybe I'm not as ready to settle down as you are, but that doesn't mean I love you any less. Got it?
Got it.  12. He gives her a reassuring hug.
Good. Welcome to Nebraska. Vicky looks out the window.
A large official sign welcoming drivers to the state. WEL

text: It continues past the sign, burrowing into a vast sea of cornfields.

We have seen glimpses of Gatlin before, but things now - three years later - are far more tranquil and idyllic. It just a tiny farm community not even on the map, out in th middle of nowhere. Like everything else in this state, it surrounded by cornfields.

stands at the edge of where the cornfield meets the town. Three children are hiding behind it, pressed against the side. They are Job and Sarah, whom we've met, and JOSEPH, is much older and larger at 14. All three are dressed in black cloth clothes of simple design, not unlike the Amis Mennonites. Joseph has a suitcase with him and appears extremely nervous, to the point of desperation. As CAMERA MOVES IN SLOWLY, we hear JOB'S CONTINUING VOICE OVER NARRATIVE.
We were with Joseph when he ran away. He was pretty scared. I wasn't.
(whining, frightened) I'm scarrrrrred!
Me tooooooo.  13.
There's nothing to be afraid of. I said I'd come back for you. I promise.
Can't we go with you? Pleeeease?
No! I'd never make it with you two.
But we don't like it here!
I said you'll be alright. (beat) As long as nobody finds them pictures you been drawing. Sarah averts her eyes and tugs sheepishly at her dress.
She can't help it.
That won't matter to Isaac and Malachai. They'll take it asa sign. Anyway, you know crayons and drawings are forbidden.... just like having a record player.
But we like it! Isaac doesn't let us do anything.
Well you just better mind him 'til I get back, or else you know what happens. He punctuates his conversation with constant glances towa the town and, more particularly, the corn. Job picks up o this.
You're not goin' through the corn are you? This apparently bodes ill. Joseph swallows hard and looks out over the field.  14.
It is serene, but dense and unyielding. A threat.
Can't go no other way.
But what about....? She doesn't finish. She doesn't need to.
It'll be alright, unless you tell anybody I'm gone.
We won't.
Cross your heart and hope to die, stick a needle in your eye?

nod in agreement like two good little soldiers. They cros their hearts with their fingers and then motion as if sticking something in their eyes. It is a children's oath taken in the way of children - with the utmost solemnity sincerity.

Okay. You know what that means. If you tell you're gonna burn on the lake of fire for all eternity. Their eyes widen in fear at the prospect. Joseph turns hi attention to the cornfield. He's sweating profusely.
Make sure nobody's looking!
Job and Sarah race to the town side of the barn and look cautiously around. Simultaneously they shout back to Jose at the tops of their lungs.  15.
He cringes at the volume and rolls his eyes in disbelief. deep breath and he's off into the corn.
They stand there watching disappointedly as their friend makes good his escape. They remain fixed, frightened and silent.

A long, flat, straight, strip of black tape separating a of golden-tipped, green corn on either side. There is something alien, remote, about this landscape. A DOT appe in the distance, growing larger.
Becomes the blue Thunderbird, which whips by. CAMERA FOLL IT, picking up a faded WOODEN SIGN by the roadside.
Reads GATLIN 7 MILES.
Burt and Vicky are bored and quiet, lost in separate thoughts.
Deserted, dilapidated, a roadside skeleton that hasn't be attended in years.
So now we know. The back roads are even less interesting than the highway. Vicky smiles sympathetically. She reaches for the radio.
Maybe they've discovered music...  16. She flips the knob and a PREACHER'S VOICE fills the car
Hallelujah!
Hallelujah!
The Lord has said that there are many mansions in His house. But there's no room there for the fornicator! Burt and Vicky give each other a look. This is a goof.
(loud)
No room for the hommasexshull!
No room for the abortionist, nor the drug abuser, no room for rock and roll music!
When are they gonna find out that the wages of sin are paid in the hot, hot halls of... Vicky turns the dial sharply before the preacher can fini All she gets is static.
Hallelujah, amen, peanut butter, white bread, and Donnie and Marie.
No room for the college graduate! No room for people who watch public television!
No room for commitments.  17.
Amen!

Joseph is running scared through the corn. He struggles against the thick, unyielding stalks and is sweating and breathing heavily. He stops every few yards to listen for sounds of pursuit and also to get his orientation.

He stops, changes direction, stops again and looks up at sun. He is lost and fighting against his panic. The corn begins to RUSTLE ominously. Joseph does an abrupt about f and runs face first into a heavy ear. It thuds against hi cheek, raising a welt.
It continues to run the steady, gauntlet of corn.
CAMERA IS LOOKING OUT FROM the cornfield, as if the plant themselves were watching. The car goes by.

With the approaching vehicle. It abruptly slows down and pulls over onto the narrow shoulder that separates the asphalt from the corn. There is a claustrophobic sense ab proximity of the stalks. Burt’s door opens.
Burt gets out. Vicky remains inside but the windows are o
What are you doing?
Corn looks a little dry.
Can I watch?
Better not. It leads to insanity.  18. He walks up to the wall of corn. It's imposing, and it st him.
That's okay. I'm crazy about you anyway. Burt is transfixed by the corn. He doesn't respond, or ev turn around.
Burt? Is anything wrong? That snaps him out of it. He looks back at her and smiles
No. Be back in a sec. He starts to go into the field.
The corn rustles ever so slightly in front of him, but th is no breeze. Burt stops like he's just walked into a wal of glass.
(to Vicky) Did you see that???
She's still in the car, leaning out the window.
No. What? A beat.
I guess it was nothing.
Oh boy! Somebody's been in the car too long.
(not convinced) Yeah.  19. With a hint of apprehension, he submerges into the field. swallows him instantly.

Joseph is utterly terrified. He's moving quickly through corn, suitcase in hand, like someone who knows he's being followed. He hears what sounds like giggling up in front him. He runs to the side but is stopped by DELIBERATE and TAUNTING NOISES in that direction. The SOUNDS ARE GLEEFUL and seem to be made by children. Joseph turns again and again, but every-time is stopped. A circle is closing aro him. He is trapped, and covered with parts of corn plants
Vicky gets out of the car and walks towards the corn.
Burt? Are you alright? Nothing.

Say something. Anything. I'm all ears. (beat) Burt, that was supposed to be funny. The only answer is a SOFT, RUSTLING SOUND from the impenetrable field. It's almost like a whisper, and it spooks Vicky a little.

is standing in the corn listening to that rustling. Somet touches his shoulder and he whips around. A CORNSTALK is leaning on him. As he shoves it aside, A CORN LEAF pokes neck. Burt is starting to get agitated. He begins to RUN.

Joseph is running also, but now with a sense of futility. His direction changes constantly and his terror is even greater than before. He trips over an ear of corn and fal down.  20. Before he can get up, A HAND ENTERS THE FRAME and grabs h by the shoulder. Joseph utters a squeak of fright, the so of a bird caught in a hunter's snare.
Burt is still running. The corn seems to be rustling all around him, but that might be from the commotion he's mak He shoves ears and stalks and leaves out of his way frantically. SUDDENLY...
Vicky crashes into him from the blind side. He grabs violently in a reflex reaction.
Well, if this is how it affects you, we’ll have to come here more often! Burt stares at her, catching his breath. He continues clutching her shoulders.
Vicky!
You were expecting maybe Jaqueline Bisset? Burt wraps his arms around her. It is at once a gesture o relief, friendship, protectiveness and sensuality.
I knew you were kinky.
Let’s get out of here.
Why? Things are starting to get interesting. (beat) You alright?
I just got turned around a little. But let’s go.  21.
(reluctant) Okay.... He starts to guide her straight ahead. She pushes him on angle.
That way. They exit the cornfield.
Burt and Vicky emerge from the cornfield and get into the car. Just before Burt ducks into the driver's side, he gi the corn a long, last look.
It is silent and still.
Burt gets in and the T-bird drives away.
Begins to rustle quietly.

Joseph is flat on his back, panting and struggling, tryin get away from Malachai, who has pinned him to the ground a knee and an arm. Others must be holding Joseph by the f from the way he's stretched out. Corn silk is plastered t his neck and face, glued there by the sweat.

A CIRCLE OF CHILDREN tightens around Joseph. They begin humming in an eerie, atonal way. A HAND grips Joseph's ha and jerks his head back. The boy's eyes widen, a look of sheer terror coming over him. Malachai raises a cornhuske knife over him. The humming increases in intensity.
Safe within the car, Burt and Vicky have calmed down considerably.  22.
I don't know what came over me. I never had claustrophobia before.
Maybe it was just cornophobia.
It sure could’ve been that. I’m even ready to get back on the highway.
I think it wasn’t too far on the map.
CAMERA TRACKS the car as it slams past us from right to l It passes another old SIGN.
In the shape of an arrow and made of rotting wood. It rea

Joseph is staggering TOWARDS THE CAMERA, which is PULLING BACK, KEEPING PACE. His eyes are blank and bulging. His hands are up to his throat and blood is flowing through h fingers, bright and sparkling. The front of his shirt is sodden with the red fluid. In effect, he's dead on his fe He's heading out of the cornfield although he doesn't kno it. Behind him we see a trail of twisted, broken corn pla with blood splashed on them. In the far background is Joseph's SUITCASE.
Vicky is fishing through the glove compartment, looking f the map. She has PAPERS, TISSUES, HAND-WIPES, A COMB, THE CAR REGISTRATION, everything in her hand but the map.
Here it is. She extracts it from a STUCKEY'S BAG on the floor. A WAD DRIED KETCHUP stains the front.  23. She begins unfolding it across the dash. She studies Burt with a knowing smile.
I wonder how it got in there....?
Joseph, reeling like a drunk, comes to the edge of the cornfield. He looks inhuman, like a macabre doll.
Vicky and Burt are studying the map, which partially obsc their view through the windshield. Vicky is pointing.
You see? This way goes to Grand Island, and this looks like it cuts out towards the highway.
Where's this "Gatlin" we've been seeing signs for?
I don't know. It's not on here. Burt leans over closer.
It has to be... Something causes Vicky to look up. ANGLE — VICKY Shock, then horror, registers on her face. She's speechle for a beat.
Joseph staggers out onto the road, directly into the path the onrushing car. His hands are still at his throat and knees are already buckling.
Vicky barely has time to scream.  24.
Burt jerks his head up, sees the boy, hits the brakes and goes into a swerve all in one motion.
Everything happens extremely fast. Amidst the sound of screeching tires and brakes, the T-bird begins to skid. There's a loud THUMP as it strikes Joseph's body, which w crumpling even before impact.
The car continues to skid and we can't see whether it actually runs over the body or just hits it, but we can s that it's in grave danger of overturning.

Burt is fighting the wheel. The tires are still screechin Vicky is one long, piercing scream. As the car comes toa shuddering, quivering halt, she is thrown face first into windshield. Burt, wearing his seatbelt, goes forward and sharply. There's silence except for the sound of the idli motor.
Burt moves quickly. He rips off his seatbelt and cradles Vicky in his arms, examining the nasty bruise that has already formed on her cheekbone.
Are you alright??? Can you feel my hand??? Vicky hasn't really composed herself yet. She's whimperin softly. Burt runs his hand over her face.
There's a contusion and swelling. It doesn't feel like anything’s broken.
That was an animal, right Burt? Please tell me it was an animal.  25. Burt suddenly remembers the boy.
I've got to go back there. You stay here and sit quietly. Don't move.
Burt knows it was no animal he hit. He stares at the heap lying in the road about 100 feet back that is reflected i the mirror. He prays silently for a sign of movement, but there is none.
Burt gathers himself quickly and bolts from the car.
Joseph's body lies face down, turned away from Burt, who kneels beside it. He puts his hand to the boy's neck, fee for a pulse, and is confused when he withdraws his hand.
It's covered with blood.
Burt turns the body over. It flops boneless, lifelessly, its back. The eyes are open and we can see very plainly t Joseph's throat has been cut from ear to ear.
Burt grimaces and loses his breath for a beat. Then he closes Joseph's eyes - a deeply tender gesture - and make momentary calculation. Vicky's voice interrupts.
Is he....?
Oh yeah.
Vicky turns away suddenly and gags. Burt rushes to her.
Oh my God....  26. Burt comforts her and starts leading her back to the car.
Vick, there's something terribly wrong here. I want you to get in the car and wait for me, and keep the doors locked no matter what.
Why? What are you going to do?
I'll tell you when I get back. Just do what I say. Vicky is alarmed, both by what he isn't telling her and w he is.
No! Where are you going??? They reach the car. Burt opens the door for her.
I have to get the body. And I want to look at something.
What?
Vicky! Please! She debates for a beat, then slips into the car. terribly shaken and pale.
Burt opens the trunk and rearranges things to make room. He takes out a BLANKET, then turns and looks back at the body, and also takes out a TIRE IRON.
She is Although we don't see who it is at first, someone watches Burt goes back to the body and gently covers it with the blanket.  27.
Walks over to the mangled portion of the cornfield where Joseph exited. He studies the twisted, broken and blood- covered stalks. All of his senses are alert.
Deep in, he spots Joseph's suitcase.
Burt makes a decision. He checks the car, looks all aroun and finally, tentatively, walks into the corn-field.

Vicky is in shock, resting dazedly in the front seat. Her head is back against the headrest and her eyes are closed She's sobbing softly. If her eyes were open, she would see Malachai emerge from corn about 50 feet ahead. She would see him pause, the bl cornhusker's knife still in his hand, and then approach t car. She doesn't see this, BUT WE DO.
He is moving carefully, alertly, through this jungle. He holds the tire iron ready and turns in every direction as moves forward. The suitcase is just up ahead in a clearin

Vicky comes out of her stupor and looks through the windshield. She sees Malachai standing in front of the ca with his malignant stare. VICKY SCREAMS and lunges for th car horn. She pounds on it, frantically looking behind he for any sign of Burt, then whips around to see that, Mala is gone.

He is kneeling by the suitcase. HE HEARS THE CAR HORN but doesn't respond immediately; perhaps thinking she is just getting impatient. The suitcase is in a clearing. There i much blood here, still fresh. The suitcase is splattered it. Suddenly, the corn begins to rustle in that weird way again. Burt looks up at the towering stalks. They seem to be closing in on him.  28.
Vicky is unglued. She gets out of the car, near hysteria. She begins to walk back towards the body.
Burt? Burt, where are you?

There is no sign of Burt. No sign of Malachai either. In fact there is no sign of anyone or anything other than th endless, ubiquitous corn and the blanket covered body lyi stubbornly in the middle of the road.
Vicky approaches the body. She cups her hands to her mout and begins to cry. She is unable to take her eyes off of She kneels next to it.

(to body) You poor thing. You poor, dear boy. And suddenly, violently, Joseph lurches up, causing the blanket to fall away from his hideous, blood drenched bod and deathly white face. He reaches for Vicky's neck. She screams and jumps back, continuing to scream and back ped until....
Someone grabs her from behind and she whirls with a start finding herself face to face with Burt. She aborts anothe scream when she sees who it is.
Vicky! She stares at him, all the trauma beginning to be too muc for her. Burt realizes this. He puts down the suitcase an shakes her.
VICKY!! VICKY!!! Get a hold on yourself! She flings herself at him. Burt holds her closely.
Oh Burt! Where'd you go??? I kneeled down next to...  29. She suddenly remembers and whips around.
It remains how and where it has been. The blanket covers TwO SHOT Vicky looks at Burt again, genuine confusion in her eyes.
He sat up. He tried to grab me...
(gentle, compassionate) It's alright. Everything's going to be alright. I'm here now. But the look on his face tells us he isn't quite convince himself. He hands Vicky the suitcase.
Take this. Come on, we’1ll go back to the car. I’ve got to get the body.

And we shall not fail Him, for He is the true God, the only God, and His message has been planted within us as the corn seed is put into the ground. (rising) Make sacrifice unto Him. Bring Him the blood of the Unbelievers 1 Malachai jumps to his feet and shouts in a killing fervor
Make sacrifice! The group, stirred by this, rises to its feet also.

Make sacrifice! Yes! They start their chanting again. The CAMERA is by now on a CLOSE-UP of The Blue Man's face It FILLS THE SCREEN, those bulging eyes staring out at us The humming grows in intensity.

Job and Sarah are sitting on the dusty porch of the house where we first saw them (inside). They're still dressed i their costumes. They look like caricatures of two anachronistic, broken down aristocrats.  58.
Now what do we do?
I wanna get out of here.
How?
Like Joseph.
No.
Why not? If he can do it, so can we. Sarah leafs through a pile of manila paper she has next t her. She extracts one and hands it to Job.

It shows us, in Sarah's innocent style, what we DID NOT s happening to Joseph - Malachai (in stick figure) pulling oversized knife across the helpless boy's throat. A numbe other children watch gleefully. There is blood everywhere spewing out into the corn.
Job starts to whimper.
I don't like Malachai. I want my mommy and daddy!
They're gone, Jobie. They're in the corn.
It's not fair! I wish Isaac never came here!
(resigned) He's always been here. Just like He Who Walks Behind The Rows.  59. They sit there on the edge of the porch, legs dangling ov the side, Job pouting and Sarah contemplating.
Another old and weather-beaten sign. It reads: YOU ARE NO

head_text.subj: ENTERING GATLIN, NICEST LITTLE TOWN IN NEBRASKA POPULATIO

text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to show the highway and the corn. The t bird ENTERS THE FRAME and we follow it down the road. We A BARN rising above the edge of the corn-field in the nea distance. Written on it in large, white letters is the legend: ONLY JESUS SAVES
Vicky is leaning against the door staring out the window. She looks haggard and beaten.
We should’ve come this way the first time.
Would it have saved that old man? Burt looks at her, surprised by the question and concerne the tone.

I don’t know. Hopefully the police will be able to figure that out. They drove for a moment. Vicky begins to giggle. Burt loo at her with even more concern. The giggle is a stream tha turns into a river. She presses her hand to her mouth, trying to suppress a hysterical laughter, a laughter of catharsis and relief.
What are you laughing at?
Did you see those signs? The ones on the side of the road? Gales of laughter now.  60.
There! There are some more. Slow down.
They border the right side of the road. There's a single word stenciled on each wooden "board. The entire set read
Vicky's laughter is subsiding, but slowly. She's had a mu needed belly laugh. Burt doesn't really think it's funny, he's glad Vicky does.
(wiping tears) They only forgot one thing.
What's that?
"Burma Shave."
Honey, are you sure you're alright? She finally stops laughing, but dabs her eyes with a tiss
I will be. Just as soon as we're a thousand miles from here in sunny, sinful California with the Rocky Mountains between us and all this. (beat) Look, here are some more.
Breasting a hill. Gatlin appears in the distance.
As Vicky and Burt get their first glimpse of the town.

Looks like a swingin' place.  61. EXT. GiATLIN - BURT & VICKY'S POV - DAY We get our first full glimpse of the town. It's in a dip the bottom of a hill. There's ONE MAIN STREET, a few cros streets, A PARK in the center and a few dusty elms. Just sleepy little town dozing in the summer sun.
Burt and Vicky are checking out the town. There's a quiet tense apprehension about it that they share.
Looks like The Twilight Zone.

The car is cruising at a moderate speed. It passes a few residential side streets. The houses are American Gothic wooden, white paint, porches - but nothing moves. So it seems. There are no cars, trucks, bicycles, people; no ki playing stickball or retired farmers smoking corncob pipe their porches.
What Burt and Vicky don't see, however, are eyes that are upon them. A FACE, watching from an attic window, disappe behind a lace curtain.

The car now passes a BRICK BUILDING. This sign on the yellowed, patchy, front door reads: PUBLIC LIBRARY. With luck it contains 500 books. TWO BOYS rise slowly froma crouched position by the side of it. They watch the passi t-bird intently.
It is old, dusty, and locked up. Bags of feed and fertili are piled high. FIVE CHILDREN, three males and two female stare through the window. THEIR POV - THE STREET - DAY The thunderbird rolls by.
Burt and Vicky are feeling more and more apprehensive. There's obviously something wrong here. Burt is going ver slowly, almost reluctant to proceed further into this pla  62.
I guess nobody told them we were coming.
I hope not.
Ah, hell, they're probably all out under a tent somewhere singing Praise The Lord. Vicky isn't convinced.
The car slows to a stop in front of HAN SEN'S COFFEE SHOP scene of the opening carnage. Like every other place in t town, it looks empty and deserted.
Burt and Vicky are checking it out.
Let's see if there's a phone.

Unless a ghost is using it. Unlike when we last saw it, there is no sign of what went here. All of the tables and chairs are set up, the booths clean and the counter spotless. The only thing lacking is any sign of recent use.
As Burt and Vicky enter. The door closing behind them muffles a sound from the kitchen.
A BLACK SLEEVED ARM reaches to a butcher block and picks CLEAVER.

Burt is trying the pay phone with no luck. Vicky is looki at the CHALKBOARD on the counter. It says: TODAY’S SPECIA MEAT LOAF CORN FRITTERS MOM HANSEN’S HOMEMADE PIE $2.74. Vicky runs her finger along the counter and looks at the dust. Burt hangs up the receiver disgustedly.  63.
Nothing. Not even a dial tone.
TwO BOYS sneak along the side of the car. They carry side and keep low, out of sight
Burt and Vicky are about to leave when they hear a NOISE the kitchen. Burt starts towards the kitchen door but Vic grabs him.
Burt! Please! Don't go in there.
Why not? It might be somebody.
Please! Something's wrong. I can feel it. I've been feeling it ever since we got here. Let's just get in the car. Now. We'll drive to Hemingford. Or Grand Island. Anywhere.
Vicky, you're really spooked. Come on, take it easy.
Please. Humor me. TI don't want you to go in there! The urgency in her voice, her insistence, wins him.

Alright. But at least let's look around some more. There's got to be somebody. And just as they turn towards the front door, Burt spots two "somebodys" messing with the car. They've got the doo open and are trying to sneak in.
Hey! Get away from that car!  64.
The boys, both around 12, dart off, leaving the door open Burt dashes out after them, several steps ahead of Vicky, isn't quick enough to catch them
See that? Just like "back home. Leave your car for two minutes and look what happens. He hurries back to the driver's side and gets in.
Get in. I don't want to lose them. She follows him into the car quickly.
It lurches forward in the direction the boys ran.
What are you going to do when you catch them?
Ask them where I can find some help. What else? (beat) Damn! Where'd they go?

There's no sign of the boys. No sign of anyone. Up ahead see the main part of town. There's a REXALL, a FIVE & DIM the GRACE BAPTIST CHURCH with its towering steeple, and n to that, the three-story GATLIN MUNICIPAL BUILDING.
(nervous) Look, we're already in the car. Why don't we just continue on to Hemingford. It'll take us twenty minutes.
But we've found people.
Yeah. A couple of kids who tried to break into our car.  Burt debates.
There is something strange about this place. After the way the old man acted...
And what happened to him. The thought chills her.
Maybe you're right. We might be better off in a larger town anyway. He makes a U-turn in the middle of the street and starts heading out of town. Something stops him OFF SCREEN.
Over there!
What?
I saw a door open and close. That house.
I didn't see anything.
Let's check it out.
Why? I thought we were going.
Yeah, but if we know somebody's here....
We don't know anything. I was looking over there. I didn't see it.
Vick...Settle down. This is not a lab experiment, we don’t need all the answers... He starts driving towards the house. 65.  66.
Don't patronize me, Burt.
I'm not. I saw the door swing open. A quick look. It can't hurt. Vicky doesn't answer him. They pull up in front of the house.
Burt is up the steps to the porch in two bounds. Vicky ta longer. She's nervous and sullen. Only a SCREEN DOOR separates them from the inside. Burt shouts through it.
Hello? Anybody home? He bangs on the frame a few times.
Hello? We've had an accident. we'd like to use your telephone.
You see? I told you. Now can we go? Burt frowns. He pauses for a beat, then opens the door an pokes his head in.
Burt! This is somebody's house!
Precisely. And all we want to do is use their phone. He enters the house. Reluctantly, Vicky follows.
There's a living room off to the left, a dining room to t right, and a staircase straight ahead. Other rooms are in back.

What isn't broken or cracked is worn, torn or faded. The upholstery on the couch in the living room looks as if someone took a knife to it  67. The stuffing has been gouged out of the seat. A cracked picture frame hangs lopsidedly over it.
Burt and Vicky look at each other. Neither likes the feel about this place.
I’1l check the back. CAMERA FOLLOWS BURT behind the staircase and into the kitchen.
In disrepair and disuse, like the rest of the house, it d contain one item of interest to Burt. A TELEPHONE. He gra the receiver and raises it, but never gets a chance to di
Cut. It dangles uselessly from the receiver.
Vicky watches as Burt walks out holding the useless phone with its severed wire.
I found a phone.
Well, it certainly goes with the decor.
Back door was open too. Whoever I saw must've slipped out. Probably one of those kids I chased off.
Yeah. Who else would avoid us! I mean, it's not like we've got a body in the trunk.
Now, now.
Why don't we sit down and make ourselves comfortable. (MORE)
VICKY(cont'd) I'm sure nobody'1ll mind if we pour the first drinks. Then when the City Council shows up....

Okay, I surrender. We're going. He moves towards the front door under her triumphant star conceding tacitly her right to be annoyed. They're about leave when A FLOORBOARD CREAKS above, They hear it and FR simultaneously.
Don't you dare. Burt is like a puppy who's spied a squirrel up in a tree. thinks he has. He shushes her, his eyes never leaving the ceiling as he moves towards the staircase.
Burt! This is ridiculous! I'm getting really angry.
(whispering) Come on, Vick! Don't you want to know who it is? Why they're hiding from us? This whole thing is so bizarre.

(shouting whisper ) All the more reason to get out now! Burt is already walking up the stairs. Very slowly and quietly, his eyes constantly on the landing above. Vicky pouts and sulks and sighs and fidgets at the bottom, know she's unable to stop him. His curiosity is contagious as as she'd like to deny it.
Burt slinks up the staircase like a cat stalking an unsuspecting bird. ANOTHER NOISE, FOLLOWED BY FOOT-STEPS. stops and looks at Vicky.
As her eyes meet Burt’s. Someone is sneaking around up there. They both know it, but Vicky fears it more.

Burt gets to the first landing. He checks ahead -the stai now reverse direction - then looks back at Vicky one last time. He is visibly more tense now. He's starting to swea and his breath quickens. He takes a step forward, and cre a floorboard himself. It freezes him to the spot. After a beat, he continues.
TwO BEDROOMS and a BATHROOM are visible. A SHORT STAIRCAS leads up to a MASTER BEDROOM.
Burt steps on another loose board. It CREAKS VERY LOUDLY. Anybody waiting for him has to know where he is by that o He sucks in a breath. MORE FOOTSTEPS FROM ABOVE.
Burt is at the top landing between the two bedrooms. He l into one of them, then disappears into it.

We recognize from the bed and bulletin board that this is bedroom Sarah was sick in three years ago when her father on the phone with her mother, x just before he was murder Only now, on that bulletin board, are tacked ALL OF THE PICTURES we've thus seen of her" stick figure prophesies. The bedroom looks like it hasn't been used in a long time at least cleaned, and is dusty and full of cobwebs, but t crayon drawings on the manila paper are a child's illustrations of the nightmare that took over Gatlin.
Burt studies the drawings. He is seeing them for the firs time and they chill him to the marrow. He rips off the rendition of HE WHO WALKS BEHIND THE ROWS and stares at i
As Burt stares at it. The evil figure stares back out at him.

Just as Burt turns out of the doorway, he comes face to f with. . . . . Vicky!!! Each jumps and gasps at the same time, their hearts racking and their eyes widening.  70. Before they have a chance to rebuke each other, another N FROM UPSTAIRS. They look towards the master bedroom and n in silent agreement.

They get to the top of the short staircase and are about look into the master bedroom, in fact are craning their n and gripping each other with white knuckles from the tens when a TREMENDOUS, HORRIFIC SHRIEK scares the daylights o of them.
Vicky loses it. She screams before she can realize that i a record as the MUSIC of the oldie WIPE OUT, continues playing. Burt charges into the bedroom.

Burt stops dead in his tracks, finding himself staring do an equally frightened and surprised Sarah. Vicky enters t bedroom a BEAT later. Burt begins to laugh. Vicky joins h They laugh almost as hard as Vicky did in the car when sh saw the signs outside Gatlin, but they stop themselves wh they realize how frightened the child is.
I'm sorry. Don't be afraid. we didn't mean to scare you. Sarah is staring at them like they're from another planet She warms to Vicky, though.
Well hello! What a darling little girl. What's your name?
(sheepish) Sarah.
Sarah. That's a lovely name. I'm Vicky, and this is Burt. Sarah won't look at Burt. She steals a glance at Vicky.
Are you alone here, Sarah? She doesn't answer.  71.
Do you live here? Sarah shakes her head no.
You just come here to play? Sarah looks down at the floor. Her record finishes and sh takes it off the turntable.
Burt notices the manila paper and crayons next to her, registering the connection to the terrible pictures he's seen. He says nothing for the moment.
Are your mommy and daddy around, Sarah? Sarah answers as if that's a stupid question, but the tho of the answer saddens her anyway.
They're in the cornfield.
What are they doing there?
All the grownups are there.
Well, are they working? Or are they having some kind of meeting?
(frustrated, a little frightened) Noooo! Isaac put them there!
Isaac? Who's Isaac? Sarah shrugs defensively. She doesn't want to answer.
Tell us who Isaac is, darling.  72.
Our leader. Now Burt is getting frustrated and a little impatient.
Leader of what?

Of everybody. Burt throws up his hands and walks over to the window. He had enough of this conversation, and frankly so have I. V keeps at it with Sarah, turning even sweeter and more pat in the wake of Burt's reaction.
Could you take us to Isaac?
(very grave) Uhhhh-uhhhh.
While the conversation continues in the B.G. we watch as looks out the window and sees something that bewilders hi
Why not?

That same, immense, invisible force we saw in the cornfie just before Chester Diehl was killed is now moving toward the town. The corn is shaking wildly and the sky darkens tremendous rate. A HOWLING WIND accompanies this. It soun ALIVE.
He looks away for a second, blinking his eyes in disbelie
He's scary! Burt looks out at the cornfield after his momentary respi
(to Sarah) (MORE)
VICKY(cont'd) Sarah, it's very important that we speak to some grownups as soon as possible. Is there anyone around that you can think of?
Nothing. No sign of what Burt saw a moment ago.
Burt rubs his eyes and accepts the possibility that stres getting to him. He walks back to Vicky.
They're gone.
Gone where?
Into the corn! Burt intervenes.
We're not getting anywhere with this, Vick.

Give her a chance, honey. She keeps saying the townspeople are out in the cornfield. (to Sarah) Right, sweetheart? All of the grownups are in the corn? Sarah nods affirmatively. There is a chilling quality to innocence with which she does this.
I tell you what, then. You stay here with her. I want to go look in that municipal building.
(alarmed) Why?  74.
Why? Because we've got a double murder to report and we're standing here with a pint sized version of Catherine the Great trying to make sense out of what happened to all the people in this town.
I just thought she could help us.
I know. Maybe you're right. She's all we have for the moment anyway. At least let's not lose track of her.
Alright. Maybe somebody will come for her.
If they do, you just bring them over to the car and hit the horn. I'll keep an eye open. He kisses her lightly and heads for the door. The reality his departure suddenly makes Vicky nervous.
Burt?...Do you think it's...safe? A beat. Burt isn't sure, but he doesn't want to scare her
For who?
For either of us?
Yeah. Weird, but safe. He smiles, and is gone.
Burt closes the front door, the wooden one behind the scr and makes sure it's locked securely. He gets into the car  75.

Burt walks towards the center of town, checking everywher for signs of people. The sidewalks are empty, storefronts dark and silent. There's no one to be seen anywhere. Only sense at Burt being followed.
CAMERA TRACKS Burt ACROSS THE PARK in the center of town. see THE POND in the middle of this park.
The solitary car passes the Grace Baptist Church. Cornshu have been heaped in the doorway. The letters in the front sign haven't changed for three years. They read CORN DROU
As the car goes by, A PREGNANT TEENAGE WOMAN steps out of shadows and glares at it. She hurries inside. This RACHEL DEIGAN.
Burt turns to look behind him, CAMERA hides as Burt turns onto the main drag and studies the buildings.
Wares are displayed "but we can barely see them for the d on the window. Something has been written in the dirt.
The message: HE WHO WALKS BEHIND THE ROWS SEETH ALL
The next building over. Cornshucks and corn leaves have b piled in the doorway and inside the display cases. ANGLE — THE CAR It continues its Stygian journey.
He passes the Gatlin Grade School. HE MOVES UP THE STEPS INSIDE.  76.
APPROACHING THE BLACKBOARD from the door, we see A CORNCO CRUCIFIX hanging in the center of the black-board. Underneath, in chalk, is written: I HAVE WITHDRAWN MY HAN

head_text.subj: FROM THEM SAITH THE LORD GOD OF HOSTS, AND THEY SHALL PAY

text: Burt pulls up in front of the building. He climbs the ste to a pair of WOODEN DOORS. There's A DRIFT OF CORN HUSKS the top step and another CORNCOB CRUCIFIX hung on each of doors. Burt looks at these thoughtfully for a moment growing more grim by the second. He goes inside.
Sarah is sitting on the floor, Vicky on the bed. Vicky tr to calm herself by calming Sarah.
Well, I guess it's just you and me. Sarah smiles at her. She is a lot less nervous than Vicky
So tell me, what were you doing here all by yourself? Just playing records? Sarah balks, tugs at her dress.
Ah, come on. You can tell me. Sarah looks at her, wondering if she can trust her, then gives in. She points to her paper and crayons.
Drawing? What's so secret about that?
Not supposed to.
You're not supposed to draw?  77. Sarah nods affirmative.
Says who? Isaac? A negative shake of the head from Sarah.
Malachai.
Malachai? Now who's....Never mind. I tell you what. You draw me a picture and we'll just not tell Malachai, or Isaac, or anyone at all. How about it?
(brightening) Okay. She arranges the paper and crayons and begins drawing. Sh so sweet and adorable that Vicky can hardly take her eyes of her.
Burt pushes through the doors and steps into the LOBBY of building. What we see is not what he sees. We see, briefl scene from three years ago.

off of which are several doors, all with frosted glass an black lettering. One says: BUREAU OF REGISTRATION, anothe is: DEEDS and a third says: DOG OFFICER. In the back is a SIGN that designates: RESTROOMS.

The room is lively and full of people. THE MUNICIPAL WORK of Gatlin, country folks in casual attire, are crowded ar A TRIO OF YOUNG CHILDREN who are handing out LEMONADE, an charging quarters for it. The kids have brought a PORTABL STAND into the room, complete with pitchers, ice and a si and a cup for change, and the adults are finding themselv amused and refreshed.  78. It takes a moment for the deadly poison in the drink to t effect, and as the shocked and confused people are trying figure out what's happening to them, AN OLDER GROUP of TEENAGERS, led by Malachai, charge in with their slaughte weapons. They cut their helpless victims down mercilessly

The RESTROOM DOOR opens and POLICE CHIEF BILL HOTCHKISS c out straightening his belt. He sees the carnage and freez So do the murderers. They hadn't expected this. Hotchkiss dumbfounded and horrified, but he has the presence of min flee just as a half dozen of the demonic kids leap out at with their weapons.
Malachai expertly throws a knife after the police chief, Hotchkiss has slammed shut the door. The knife buries its in the wood.

As he scans the quiet, empty room. There are no bodies, b the place is a shambles. Desks, chairs and tables are overturned, filing cabinets are down, and everywhere is C dried, brittle and yellowed with age.
Burt passes a BULLETIN BOARD upon which are several notic Prominent among them is one that advertises: OLD FASHIONE

CARL BRUCKNER "OBEDIENCE TO AUTHORITY IS OBEDIENCE TO GOD
HEAR LILY TREMENT, THE SINGING MARVEL PLUS "THE GOSPEL SI

text: As he reads this, something flashes in his mind.
to Sarah's drawing of the revival meeting in the corn whe the child usurper (Isaac) shoved the minister aside.
Burt turns away and goes to the door marked BUREAU OF REGISTRATION. He begins to open it.

The house in which are Vicky and Sarah. A BLACK HAT COMES INTO FRAME, and then the body of the BOY wearing it. He i dressed in the black, cloth uniform we have seen. CAMERA WIDENS TO INCLUDE more than A DOZEN COMPANIONS. They are oldest boys we have seen, between 15 and 18 years old, an some of them are pretty big. All of them are scary. They have a hungry, lethal glint in their eyes. They've formed big semi-circle around Malachai, and they're humming thei weird song as they close in. All are armed.
Burt is exploring the office. It's a shambles, like the other room, and corn is heaped everywhere in here too.
He takes all this in with growing bewilderment. Then helo up at the far wall and we see his eyes widen with surpris

It's dominated by the strangest PORTRAIT OF CHRIST we've seen. We know it's Christ but even so, there's a stronger resemblance to Lon Chaney in "The Phantom Of The Opera." Christ is grinning and he has green hair but, after a mom we see it really isn't hair at all but rather corn plants

Burt crosses the room to the picture and takes it off the wall, standing on a chair to do so. He stares at the hide corruption for a moment and then smashes it on the floor. isn't out of control, but the image has affected and offe him deeply. He heads for the door

CAMERA LINGERS on the window as Burt exits. Slowly, one b one, THREE BOYS, all crowned in BLACK RIMMED HATS, look i us and scan the now vacant office. They hold a brief, whispered conversation and then duck OUT OF VIEW.

Shadows are beginning to fall across Gatlin as the sun is getting low.  80. The ominous circle of boys moving towards the house has broken up into two's and three's. A few are at the front door, which is locked.
Two more find a basement window ajar and wriggle in.
Another group applies a crowbar to a living room window.
Sarah is still working on her picture. Vicky enters from another room.
How's it coming?
Fine.
What is it?
(innocent, angelic) You.
(delighted) Oh! Can I see?
Yes. She finishes a couple of strokes and hands the picture to Vicky.
Her face goes from bemused to horrified to repelled as sh looks at the picture.

We can tell from Sarah's expectant face that she has absolutely no idea that what she's drawn is bad in any wa Vicky is about to rebuke her when we hear the sound of GL BREAKING. Vicky whips around and looks out the doorway.
Burt climbs the stairs to the THIRD FLOOR. He's tired, sweating heavily, and beaten. He pulls the door open and exits into a dark corridor.

PAINTED IN RED along the wall, which ends at a FIRE ESCAP DOOR, are the words: THUS LET THE INIQUITOUS BE CUT DOWN THE TRUE GOD MIGHT COME FORTH Burt follows the words alon the wall, arriving at a pair of OFFICES on either side. O belonged to POLICE CHIEF BILL HOTCHKISS (The Blue Man) an the other to MAYOR JOHN D. REESE.
Burt turns into the police chief's office and gets a frig
A MOLDY SCARECROW, festooned with corn, is propped up in chair behind the desk. A POLICEMAN'S BADGE is pinned on t cloth shirt.
Vicky comes out of the bedroom and stops at the top of th stairs.

(anxious, tentative) Burt? Is that you? She walks down the short staircase. The answer, at first, silence. Then, softly, the humming. Vicky listens, and clutches in her right hand the picture Sarah drew. Curios gets the better of her. Ever so slowly, she tiptoes down the top of the second landing and looks down.
The humming gets louder. The Children Of The Corn begin t congregate at the bottom of the stairs. They stare at Vic through rabid eyes. Their weapons and their intent are plainly visible.
(shouts) Who are you?  82. They hum steadily. Vicky shouts even louder. She's terrified.
What do you want? The humming stops abruptly.
Malachai steps forward from the rear. He looks up at Vick with a blissed-out expression.
We want to give you peace.
Vicky figures that one out in a hurry. She lunges back upstairs, tripping and stumbling in her haste.
Malachai lets slip his pups of war.
Seize her! And with a gleeful shout, the boys rush the stairs all at once. They fall over each other in their haste to do Malachai's bidding.

Vicky runs into the bedroom SCREAMING AT THE TOP OF HER LUNGS. She slams the door and frantically pulls a CHEST O DRAWERS against it just as the first wave of boys arrives Their initial charge is dulled by the unexpected weight o the furniture, but it is obvious they won't be stopped. Vicky, still screaming, pushes against the door with all might. A HATCHET blasts through, cutting her arm and splintering the wood. Vicky screams again and clutches at arm.
The door gives way and the boys, like giant black rats, p into the room. Vicky picks up a lamp and throws it at the Sarah remains seated on the floor, frozen, staring fearfu at the proceedings.  83.

Vicky is dragged, literally, kicking and screaming from t room. Her clothes are torn, she's bleeding from the mouth arm and her face is badly bruised. She has dropped the crumpled picture on the floor.
Sarah is left untouched and alone in the room. She hasn't moved through the whole thing. Her wide, terror-stricken tell the whole story. He lip trembles.
Burt is still there, trying to figure the foreboding scarecrow, but has decided he's had enough of trying to figure anything in Gatlin. He turns around and sees a picture on the wall behind him.
It's the VIRGIN MARY, withering back from the onslaught o monstrous DRAGON. Underneath is a caption: AND WHEN THE

WOMAN WHICH BROUGHT FORTH THE MAN CHILD

text: As he reads the caption, he senses something.
He begins to move on, but something about this picture pu at him. He stares at it again.
His eyes study the dragon, and then the woman, and then t threatening dragon again....
And then Burt begins to run. He flies out the door and in the....
Running as fast as his legs can carry him, slipping on th slick floor....  84.
He "takes the stairs three at a time, two flights, and bu through the doors to the main lobby.
Burt streaks across it and crashes through the door.
The first thing Burt sees stops him momentarily.
It's wrecked; slashed, battered, the hood is up and the w ripped out; and the engine is stuffed with corn husks and plants. Burt enters frame.
Burt bolts down the stairs and past the car at a dead run His path is a trip in time. Various buildings he runs pas give us a brief glimpse of their terrible history.
Burt runs past the library.
A GROUP OF "CHILDREN" are burning its books in a big bonf outside. DOZENS OF BOOKS are tossed out the windows by th inside while the ones outside heap them on the flames. IS supervises.

Is this what you want? Another killing? Is this what your Isaac preaches? And almost as if in response, they hear Isaac's scream. I so inhuman that it distracts everyone, including Burt. Th scream is followed by ANOTHER NOISE, perhaps even more frightening and certainly less human. It's like the growl a lion, only much deeper and more potent, like water drai into a thousand foot well. It is a sound that is at once recognizable and yet unlike any we have ever heard. It should chill us to the bone.

SEVERAL OF THE BOYS runs away, so frightened are they by "declaration" from the cornfield. Burt rises to his feet, staring out at the darkness in awe and wonder. He forgets about Malachai, which is a mistake, and begins instinctiv to move towards the barn for Vicky.
Malachai scrambles to his knees. He looks at the remainin boys.

Get him! Kill him! Nobody makes a move. Malachai is stunned that they would disobey him, but he is too filled with hate to worry abou that now. He sees his knife on the ground and picks it up Rising, he prepares to throw it into Burt's back. But jus as he does...
A VOICE calls out to him. It does not sound human.  111.
Malachai! Burt hears it too, and turns around to see Malachai, the remaining Children, and the figure who has stepped out of corn and is walking towards them.

It is not Isaac, but once it was. This is a demon Isaac, hideous perversion of what used to be a little boy who wa possessed by a fanatical religion. Much of his skin has b eaten away - gnawed to the bone by some beast of nightmar His eyes are huge globes staring at something not of this world, as he is not any longer. His hair, the wisps of it that are left, seem more like corn leaves and corn silk, indeed there is a greenish tinge to what little skin he h left. His clothes are plastered with corn plants and smea with kernels. His hands, reaching outstretched for Malach are bone.
He wants you too, Malachai! He wants you too!
The half dozen Children left run past Burt into the barn. couple remain behind him and watch from the safety of his presence.

He starts backing up. Alone. The look on his face is not demonstrable terror, or horror, or fright. It is way beyo that, so far that there is little emotion left with which express what it is. He's trembling and sweating profusely His hands and feet are like lead. He tries to flee from t oncoming demon but he can't seem to move.

Isaac catches up to Malachai, hissing and growling like a animal as he leaps upon him. Malachai buries his knife up the hilt in Isaac's chest, but it doesn't even faze the smaller "boy." Isaac is already long since dead. He drags Malachai back into the corn with irresistible strength. Malachai's screams echo through the town.
Burt turns to the barn and sees that Vicky has witnessed spectacle.  112. The Children who ran into the barn are huddled around her She meets Burt halfway to the barn and they embrace passionately.

Thank God you're alright. Job and Sarah come running over to them. They're terribly upset by what they've just seen and they cling to Burt an Vicky. But just when you thought it was safe to go back i the corn...

head_text.subj: THE HOWL OF THE BEAST RISES OUT OF THE FIELD

text: Burt, Vicky and the children are physically jarred by the power of the roar. The monstrous sounds continue as light and lightning shatter the darkness, accompanied by a ragi wind that tosses debris in every direction. It's as if th monster is going to destroy the entire town.
Our "family" hurries to the relative safety of the barn.
Burt, Vicky, Job and Sarah join the other six Children wh are huddled in here, frightened out of their wits.
What do we do?
I don't know. If I knew what it was out there maybe I could tell you.
It's He Who Walks Behind the Rows.
What if we run for it. Try to make it to the road. Burt looks at the children, and Vicky's wounds.

I think we're safer here, at least for the time being. They listen as the horrendous noises continue outside. Th are slamming up against the barn walls.  113. Without warning, one of the planks explodes. The wind how in, muffling their screams of terror.
Burt goes to Job. Something has to be done.
Job, has anybody ever tried to hurt the monster? Any of the parents or adults, before they were. Job remembers what happened to them. To his parents.
(quietly) The Blue Man.
Who's the Blue Man? what did he do?
Officer Hotchkiss. The Chief of Police. He came down here after he talked to the minister. He was reading a page torn out of the bible. And then he was doing something with the still.
What stopped him?
Malachai.

Why was he reading from the bible? What was it? Job reaches into his pocket. He pulls out a COMPASS, a PE KNIFE, a RABBIT'S FOOT KEY CHAIN, TWO BASEBALL CARDS, and WALLET. He pores through a number of PAPERS he has in the wallet. Outside, the sounds of Armageddon. The barn rocks and sways to the side.
Hurry up, Job! Job finally finds what he's looking for. He hands Burt th page from three years ago.  114.

It's from REVELATIONS, CHAPTER 20. VERSE 10 is circled in RED. 20:10 And the devil that deceived them was cast into the lake of fire and brimstone, where the beast and the false prophet are, and shall be tormented day and night for ever and ever. Burt remembers something.
Just after the black-robed girl stabbed Burt and he fell the pile of bibles, he noticed a page had been torn from of them.
Burt fights his frustration. He looks at Vicky, who has read the page over his shoulder.
I don't know what it means! Another plank explodes. And another. They duck out of the way of the splintering boards.
(shouting, to Job) What was the Blue Man doing at the still?
He hooked the hose up to it and was rolling it out. Burt ponders.
Lake of fire...Fire! He must have been trying to burn the field.  115.
But how?
With the...Never mind. Burt springs into action. He becomes the Field General of this motley fighting force.

You kids I Get me all the hoses you can find. Job, Sarah, find a glass bottle, a soda pop bottle if you can. Vicky, come here. Burt leads Vicky over to the GASOHOL DRUMS. He takes the from one of the kids. It won't connect to the spigot
(to kid) Give me your knife. The innocent looking boy hands Burt a mean looking knife. Burt hands it to Vicky and holds up the hose.
Cut it. She does so. Burt jams the end onto the spigot.
(to Vicky) You're going to have to hold this tight when I go out there.
Where??? What??? Are you crazy??? Burt ignores her. He barks an order at the kids.

Connect those hoses. Hurry! Job arrives with an empty, ancient bottle of PEPSI. Burt takes the hose off the spigot long enough to fill the bot with gasohol. He rips part of Job's shirt and stuffs the into the bottle. Job protests.
Hey!  116. Burt smiles and touches the boy's cheek as he shakes the bottle thoroughly, wetting the rag with the gasohol. He turns to Vicky and gives her a hard, sudden kiss.
I love you. Remember to keep that hose on tight. He jams it up against the spigot and opens the valve. Vic doesn't know what to say, so she says nothing.
Burt lights the rag with his cigarette lighter, picks up hose, from which gasohol is beginning to pour out, and ex the barn.

A scene worthy of the sounds we have just heard from insi the barn. There's a gale force wind blowing out of the cornfield. Wood, glass, corn - all kinds of debris - are being tossed about. The sky is dark but darker over the cornfield, except for the middle which is glowing and sparking. The houses and buildings of Gatlin are coming apart, both from the wind and the noise, that incredible chilling roar, emanating from the cornfield.

Burt runs with the hose and the Molotov cocktail towards sprinkler pump fixture. An even more savage roar goes up from the monster. Things begin to come out of the field, shot as if from cannons, right at Burt

At first the corn plants seem like debris. They whip arou Burt's legs, tripping him, and around his arms. While he' struggling, more are piling on top of him. He's becoming entangled in a net. Panic stricken, Burt struggles to fre himself. He's tearing at the stalks when he sees...

head_text.subj: THE BLUE MAN AND HIS CROSS

text: The crucifix and its dead occupant are about to smash Bur into the ground. He rolls out of the way just in time, barely avoiding the ten foot wooden icon. But he is still entangled in the corn stalks. Job suddenl appears with a knife. He starts hacking away at the stalk They bleed and the monster howls in protest.  117.
Burt is free. He picks up the hose and cocktail.
Get back to the barn! He runs forward. Job stays right where he is, not wanting abandon Burt.

Burt is almost at the pump when THE BODIES OF ISAAC AND MALACHI - what's left of them - are now flung upon him. H skeletons, half decaying flesh, they entangle him ina lifeless grappler hold. Burt struggles to rid himself of them and finds it isn't that easy.
He stands frozen, watching in horror.
And now the monster itself rears its head and bellows its intent. It is immense, formless, a vision of death.

Burt is working feverishly. He opens the metal cover on t pump and tries to unscrew its connecting valve. The thing won't budge. The hose is spilling gallons of gasohol by t second and is in danger of running out. He grabs another piece of loose tubing and uses it as a lever. The valve finally opens. Job arrives.
The monster moves slowly, steadly, inexorably towards Bur and Job.
Burt jams the hose into the valve. He throws the switch and...

...Nothing happens. The monster approaches. Burt and Job will never make it back to the barn. The Beast is too clo But then, the sprinklers begin to move, kicked to life by sudden increase in pressure. They begin to spew gasohol o the sacred corn.  118.

The Beast is enraged. It looses a deafening roar of prote and pain. It lifts the giant sprinklers into the air like they were toys and thrashes them, but as it does so it on gets more of the fluid on the corn, and also on itself.
Burt picks up the Molotov cocktail and heaves it. Within motion, though, he is jolted by the forgotten pain in his wounded shoulder.
The Molotov cocktail falls far short of its target. In fa it doesn't even break.
Burt, clutching his wound, stares in shock.
Oh no.... Job, realizing what has happened, begins to run straight the corn.
Job! NO! COME BACK!!!
Job is intent. His little body darts into the rows.
The monster starts towards the boy.
Burt starts towards the field, screaming to Job in vain.
Job flies past the stalks. He spots the still-burning cocktail.  119.

He scours the field with his eyes. Despair racks his body As the Beast comes within 50 yards, its immense shadow fa over him. Burt steps back, his eyes drawn upwards. He is about to die and he knows it.
Job emerges from the cornfield. He hands the flaming Molo cocktail to Burt, who is so happy to see him that he forg himself for a moment. He looks at the boy, and then incredulously at the bomb.
He waits expectantly for Burt to throw it again.
Burt heaves the cocktail as hard and as high as he can. I takes a second for it to land and then..
becoming a veritable LAKE OF FIRE. The sky turns a fiery orange-red. THE BEAST HOWLS EVEN LOUDER, registering its and rage.
Vicky and the rest of the children venture a look, so gre is the noise and the heat.
(seeing the flames) Oh my God! Buuuurrrrrt! She goes running to him, all of the Children following.
Burt and Job have been running towards the barn. They joi the others and all continue their retreat to a safer plac
They stop near the edge of town and look back on the destruction.  120.

The Devil is in his Hell. As the flames consume the field MUCH BRIGHTER AND MORE INTENSE FIRE accompanied "by tortu screaming, breaks off from the general one. The Beast is outlined and defined by this fire within the fire. It bur brighter and brighter, brilliantly for a moment, and then IMPLODES IN ON ITSELF, turning into a vortex that disappe down into the earth.

Burt, Vicky, Job and Sarah, and all of the others, watch, glow from the continuing flames casting a healing light o their faces. Vicky is leaning against Burt. In her hand, is still clutching the page from Revelations. -end-
